Exploring your living

Heart

WHAT IS THE HEART?

The heart is an organ of the human body and many animal species. It is responsible for the functioning of the circulatory system (namely the blood and lymph transport system). Its walls consist mostly of muscles, that contract and relax, pumping blood around the body 24/7.

WHAT IS ITS FUNCTION?

The main task of the heart is to pump blood all over the body. The blood transports and provides oxygen, minerals and vitamins that allow the body to move, grow and repair itself. Simultaneously, the blood collects the accumulated waste, taking it to the parts of the body responsible for the disposal (lungs, kidneys and liver).

WHAT DOES IT LOOK LIKE?

The heart is about the size of a fist and is located behind the breastbone, slightly on the left.
Inside, the heart is divided into four sections, the upper parts are called right atrium and left atrium, the lower parts are the ventricles (right and left).
The atriums (the two upper parts) communicate with the ventricles (the two lower parts) through valves. The valves work so that the blood can flow from the atrium to the ventricle but not vice versa.

RIGHT SIDE

The right side of the heart, contracting, recalls the blood that circulates in the veins of the body and sends it to the lungs. The blood that reaches the lungs is full of waste and of the carbon dioxide (CO2) that has been collected in the various organs. CO2 gets breathed out/exhaled when it reaches the lungs.

CO2 BLOOD IN LUNGS

In the lungs an exchange takes place: the blood is filled with the oxygen (O2) that comes from the breathed air and then returns to the heart.

LEFT SIDE

The left side of the heart, thanks to the arterial system, pumps oxigen-rich blood back to the various organs of the body in an endless cycle. This blood is a bright red colour.

PUMP, CLEAN AND REPEAT

LEAVING THROUGH AORTA

CIRCLE STARTS AGAIN
